PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Third Allotted Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [1st April, 2002],

    'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".' - [Mrs Lim Hwee Hua].

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of Mrs Lim Hwee Hua's motion to thank the President

Column: 246

for his Speech during the Opening of the Tenth Parliament.

    Before that, after hearing the introduction of the Bill on birds and animals, I will try and see whether I can make my point about more than just birds and bees. It is about harmony.

    We are at the crossroads, said the President. Our collective rejoinder should be, let us make sure we know which route to take. The price can be high if we were to take the wrong turn. As stakeholders, we all have vested interests in that common destination. Equal rights, however, demand equally shared responsibilities.

    Social cohesion and religious harmony are obviously the cornerstones of Singapore's future, after all, as the President had cautioned, it is one of our on-going challenges, except that it has taken a certain urgency post September 11. The earlier we recognise that, the better placed we are to prepare for the tasks ahead.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I was in Marrakech, Morocco, a fortnight ago, to attend the 107th Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference. Leading the Singapore delegation, I was proud to announce at the Conference that Singapore celebrates pluralism. Even our delegation was symbolic of that. I am glad that Mr Chiam has just walked in. Although the majority of Singaporeans are Chinese, two of the representatives were Malay/Muslims, Mr Ahmad Khalis and myself. The other delegate, Mr Chiam See Tong, is Chinese, a Christian (not from the majority Buddhists/Taoists group), and from the Opposition too. I must add that Mr Chiam is a true Singaporean, especially overseas. I dare say that I look forward to my next trip travelling with Mr Chiam as a companion.

    The IPU Conference, Sir, was also preoccupied with the issue of the global fight against terrorism. That reminded me about the UN Conference on Racism, Xenophobia and Intolerance, in Durban, a few days before the tragic and horrible attack by extremists and heartless terrorists on the World Trade Centre. Ego and emotion engulfed the minds at the

Column: 247

conference, leaving it a failure, despite being held in the Land of the forgiving Nelson Mandela.

    After September 11, the world is never the same again. But has the world really learnt its lesson? In the Middle East, the Israel-Palestinian time-bomb is fast ticking towards madness. The ghost of the Al Qaeda network continues to haunt, not only in Afghanistan but also in our backyard. The reality of the Jemaah Islamiyah arrests and the severity of the security risks they pose to Singapore still escape some. As Dr Balaji reminded us yesterday, imagine if they had chosen Singapore instead of the World Trade Centre. The sooner we realise the dangers of such extreme behaviour and take steps to minimise, if not eradicate it, the better it is.

    How Muslims interpret Islam, in particular the need to champion moderation in the modern, progressive and secular world today, will have serious ramifications on how we live together in harmony in Singapore, the region, in fact, the world. It is not just about tolerance, neither coexistence. Coexistence can be described as a relationship between a farmer and a turkey, until Christmas. That is not good enough. We do not need `cold turkey' in our multi-racial and multi-religious relations. It needs better understanding and trust. That may sound a cliche, but that is a warning or reminder worth reiterating. This will be the most important test for Singapore's resilience. Indeed, it will be the most challenging.

    Understanding Islam and the many faces of Muslims in the world today will be and must be an important agenda for us global and cosmopolitan Singapore. The concept of Ummah is important in the Islamic vocabulary, but do not misunderstand when they endeavour to be good Muslims or even religious. Muslims in Singapore, however, must be more discerning and rational in their judgment, especially when it involves extremism and conservatism. Fortunately for us, most Singaporeans are moderates, as

Column: 248

was mentioned by Mr Ahmad Magad yesterday. Nevertheless, it is always the extreme minority that is strident and vocal. They can do serious damage to the interests of the silent moderate majority, just like the Talibans and the Al-Qaeda network.

    Singapore Muslims have to be brave to go moderate and main stream, not extreme. No doubt, Muslims need to believe in the supremacy of the Koran and the Syariah, but look to the golden era of the Prophet and the Caliphs to see the open-mindedness, the emphasis on knowledge and science and technology. Not the quarrels over khilafiah or interpretations, or who is more Muslim or more sincere. The Islamic civilisation was the centre of trade, arts and sciences then, not veiled withdrawals into exclusivity and conservation.

    The President of the Moroccan Parliament told me that Moroccans are proud of their Berber civilisation, Arab-Islamic background and close to the Western European world. They did not allow one to trouble the other. They achieve harmony of thought and mind, and progress in tandem with the modern world, not secular in approach, neither totally Muslim, as would be understood by some extreme groups, but humane, which is just as Islamic to them.

    It is easy to stir trouble under the guise of defending fellow Muslim rights, but how many 'brothers' will come to our help when we are in deep waters ourselves. Muslims in Bosnia knew that. Chairman Arafat must be wondering now where will help come from. Muslims in Singapore must not allow Muslim `brothers' from outside who know little about our own developments and situation, or worse, with their own agenda, to make our challenges more complex. We have to resolve them ourselves, our way, whether tudung, madrasah or upliftment. I realise the issue of tudung in school is still bugging the minds of many Muslims, but we will have to continue to work on it. No minority extreme views should be allowed to dominate or influence the moderate majority.

Column: 249



    The President's Address highlights the challenges we face together - not Malay problem, not Chinese problem, but Singaporean challenges. Voices accusing the Government of marginalising the Malay/Muslims have been heard when convenient by certain quarters and parties, inside and outside Singapore. Sure, for a community which has been lagging behind for decades in education and the economy, one does not and must not expect miracles to turn the situation around. Even affirmative action programmes in many countries have proven inadequate. There are still many areas that need urgent attention, education in particular. The Malay community recognises that, so does its leaders. It is that awareness that has allowed the community, through its upliftment programmes, to show credible progress. The performance of Malay students in mathematics was the 7th in the world in the 1999 World Mathematics and Science Survey, surpassing the US, Canada and UK.

    Do not also say that there were no opportunities. Our first President was a Malay and we now, Sir, have yourself the Speaker of the House, a first for a Malay. The Minister in charge of Muslim Affairs is a PhD in Engineering from Stanford, and look at the new crop of MPs that we have brought in at the last general elections. With due respect to ex-teachers and journalists like myself, we have a lawyer, an international labour unionist, another PhD, a sociologist, and a polytechnic lecturer. Some may say that we have not come to the stage of producing people like the Senior Ministers of State Mr Tharman and Mr Khaw, and Ministers of State Mr Ng, Dr Balaji, Dr Balakrishnan and Mr Raymond Lim, but that should not be a point for us to gripe, neither despair, but indeed that should serve as a challenge for us to strive for.

    The community should indeed feel inspired to work even harder to uplift and together build greater resilience. When the Malay community progresses and strengthen further its educational base, the stronger will the community

Column: 250

become and thus the more resilient our multi-racial Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, listening to the President's Address makes me more convinced the importance of the CDCs. Make CDCs all the more relevant as catalysts for social cohesion. The Government needs to relook at the resources given to the CDCs to enhance their role.

    If I may use the North East CDC as an example, and I declare my interest as Mayor of North East CDC, its philosophy and basic principles not only address short term immediate problems, but also tackle future challenges. Resilience means enhancing personal responsibility where assistance is aimed at helping individuals gain self-reliance. After all, all programmes are aimed at promoting community self-help. The responsibility of any social problems must be shared between the Government, the community and individuals. The CDC's role should be that of enabler of community. The CDC provides the infrastructure and resources to facilitate all to play their part.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, ideas may be easy to come by but, more important, is the will to make multi-racial and multi-religious Singapore succeed as a more cohesive nation. For that, we need a greater sense of common destiny. That must be our shared destination, our shared responsibility. That is our road ahead.

    Sir, I support the motion.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to speak in support of the motion standing in the name of Mrs Lim Hwee Hua, Member for Marine Parade GRC.

    The President has reflected a very tough external environment and has laid out several present and future challenges for Singapore. I would like, first, to comment on economic restructuring and why we need to develop a society of creative thinkers, before moving on to propose ways to build social cohesion. I will end by

Column: 251

arguing why there is a need for more than just political renewal.

Economic restructuring and developing a society of creative thinkers

    It is well known that Singapore's economy is highly dependent on electronics and manufacturing. The manufacturing sector has served Singapore very well in the last several decades. We have virtually exported our way out, from a third world to that of a developed nation. Credit is due and must be given to the founding leaders for their wisdom and foresight in pursuing this policy.

Reducing business cost

    However, times have changed. We are now a developed economy and cost is awfully high. We are expensive and no longer cost-competitive. Our manufacturers cannot compete efficiently in terms of pricing alone. We are trying to move up the value chain and technological expertise. However, these are just ways to stall for time before other countries, like China, catch up.

    In the meantime, we need to look into ways to reduce the high cost of doing business in Singapore. Most of these high costs, like licence fees, public service charges, land cost, rental, direct and indirect taxes, transport cost and so on, can be traced to the Government. Like Mr Ravindran said, I also wonder if the public service departments are recovering costs, or making huge profits.

    Therefore, in the interim measures to make Singapore competitive, the Government should take the lead to lower these burdens and adjust them to a more competitive level. This is the best immediate way to help reduce business costs.

Developing a creative thinking society

    For the longer term, we need greater initiative to develop more unique products and services that we can export. To achieve this, we must be free to think.

Column: 252

Look at the USA - their emphasis on creativity and a free-thinking society have paid off very well economically.

    Creativity is the current buzzword in education and society. What actually constitutes creativity? Sir, I believe there are two types of creativity - artistic and thinking. I cannot speak for artistic creativity, but thinking creativity is something that we can nurture and build upon. To be a nation of creative thinkers, we must first start by getting our citizens to ask the question "Why". For example, why must we rely so heavily on Malaysia for water? Why must we fear China's economic growth? Can there not be a better solution to what the Ministers proposed? There must be other fresh solutions to Singapore's many challenges.

    Mr Sim Wong Hoo of Creative Technology must be spending a lot of time thinking, "What new products can I market to the world? How can I improve on the sound blaster card?" Sir, it is through the questioning attitude that opens our mindset to the possibility of looking for solutions out of the box. Had Sir Isaac Newton not asked, "Why did the apple drop from the tree?", he would not have gone on to discover the laws of gravity.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I agree with the Member for Ang Mo Kio GRC, Mr Wee Siew Kim, that for a truly questioning mind to be developed, it has to start from a young age. A safe and encouraging environment must be present for children to ask questions and speak their mind. This should be the priority in our schools. The Education Ministry must seriously look into this. It is not healthy for young Singaporeans to learn to keep their mouths shut - like the fishes in Jack Neo's movie "I Not Stupid".

    To have a questioning mind is the beginning of wisdom. It is more important than constant mugging for examinations or the memorising of facts and figures. We must give our only natural resource, that is, our human talents, a lot more care, encouragement and empowerment to bring them to their full potential.

Column: 253



    Although not all will turn out to be another Mr Sim Wong Hoo, at the very least, they will be equipped with the correct thinking skills to be creative thinkers. The art of asking questions will definitely kick start the thinking process, foster initiative and a sense of ownership of the problems on hand. It will break our infamous attitude of kiasu and kiasi that Mr Seng Han Thong mentioned on Monday.

    I strongly believe that a "thinking person" will be a model citizen with the `spirit of resilience and self-sufficiency' that Dr Ng Eng Hen mentioned on Monday. Their first instinct will not be to run to the MPs to ask for help, but to think of the problems, and to take the initiative to solve the problems themselves. This will certainly boost the brand name of our Singaporean professionals and managers.

Building social cohesion

(a) Develop a more tolerant, magnanimous and forgiving culture

    Mr Speaker, Sir, now I would like to move on to talk about building social cohesion.

    To continue to develop this culture of creativity and initiative, we must restructure our society and political system, allow for differences in thinking and attitudes. We must let our citizens feel real ownership of our society, not just physical ownership.

    As leaders, we must learn to agree to disagree. We can disagree professionally but we must always work together to uphold the decisions of the majority, while considering the concerns of the minority. This will provide the social glue for a more cohesive society.

    Politics is very discouraging for the young, especially for those on the opposite side of the governing party. In past elections, there were many settling of scores and law suits. This does not make a more gracious or cohesive society, especially when it is seen as a big Goliath bullying a small David.

Column: 254



    Sir, I believe as national leaders, we should learn to be more forgiving of political opponents. We should give more leeway for the heat generated during an electoral contest, and not make a big issue out of a molehill. We should be more magnanimous to those who spoke out and are highly critical of us.

    For instance, I am on talking terms with my political opponent, Prof. Low, from Chua Chu Kang. I respect him - he is not here - for his electoral victory, but I shall continue to work the ground and try to win the support of the residents there. This is civil competition. It is healthy and should be encouraged.

    "May the best person win" should be the motto of our society. This is the spirit of meritocracy.

(b) Adopt a balanced approach to managing society

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we need to take on a balanced approach to society. I believe that our society has been over-managed to the extent that Senior Minister complained there is little buzz. The Government has been taking a very top-down approach in managing our society. I agree very much with the President's view that, and I quote: "We must open up more space for Singaporeans."

    It is high time to set in motion this bottoms-up approach - to spend more time engaging and listening to the people, to understand their concerns and aspirations; to be more sensitive to their needs and wants.

    A good way to start this bottoms-up approach is by having each Residents Committee (RC) and its Chairman elected by the residents themselves. Currently, it is being appointed by the MP, and for most residents they would not know who are the Chairmen of the RCs. By being elected, they will get to know the residents better, earn their respect and be their voice to Government officials. This interaction between the community and the Government will definitely build a more dynamic society.

Column: 255



    The Government must trust the people and allow them to help shape policies that affect their lives. By empowering the people to make wise decisions, Singaporeans will be more supportive and pursue these policies wholeheartedly.

(c) Develop a sense of belonging for Singaporeans

    Regarding the President's Speech on "international talent", I agree it is important to attract these talents to Singapore. I applaud the President for his use of the term `international' over the often-controversial phrase `foreign talents'.

    I believe that not all foreigners are that talented. Some are just more outspoken or better in packaging themselves. In Jack Neo's movie, political satire, "I Not Stupid", the expatriate is only holding a very junior position in his home country and not very creative. But he became the creative director in the show because he is an expatriate. We must correct and stop this assumption that all foreigners are talented. Many are not.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there are many young Singaporeans who are equally, if not more talented. They are either not given the right opportunity or not empowered to exercise their talents. It is important that we put greater emphasis in developing this talent pool.

    We need to develop a stronger sense of belonging. Specifically, Singaporeans must have special privileges and rights that they hold dear in Singapore. If they decide to migrate overseas, they will forfeit these rights. Sir, let us all think of ways to build more privileges and rights for Singaporeans, so that even international talents may be attracted to become our citizens.

More than just political renewal

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the President talked about political renewal. I think we need more than that. Ms Irene Ng yesterday

Column: 256

had talked about the four divides. Today, I will add the fifth divide to it - the political divide, ie, the divide in the population between hardcore Opposition supporters and the Government.

    Fair political competition in Singapore is almost non-existent, and so are constructive and rational non-governing political parties. Singaporeans want and hope that the General Elections will be fairer. The use of threats and goodies, together with the last-minute announcement of new electoral boundaries, does not make elections fair to non-governing party candidates.

    Other than being known as kiasu and kiasi, Singaporeans are also known to kia zhenhu. They are afraid of offending the governing party based on - please correct me if I am wrong - the unfounded belief that their livelihood would be jeopardised. This is especially so when the ballot papers have serial numbers on the back.

    It does not help to build confidence in the electoral process, especially when the vote could potentially be traced through the serial numbers. Something must be done once and for all to convince our voters that their votes are really secret. The best way is to completely remove the serial number at the back of the ballot papers.

    Deputy Prime Minister Lee had mentioned before the last General Elections the introduction of the Fair Competition Act. It is very much our hope, Mr Speaker, Sir, that this Act will also cover fair competition in the area of politics. In line with that, the Elections Department should come under the jurisdiction of the President, instead of the Prime Minister's Office.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Leader of the House, during the debate on the motion for nomination of NMPs in the Ninth Parliament, said, and I quote:

    "As Opposition Members, they will generally take an adversarial position in the debates though sometimes they have been constructive."

Column: 257

Sir, by definition, I am from the Opposition. However, what am I opposing? We do not oppose for the sake of opposing. What is there to oppose if a policy is for the good of the people? If it is not good for the people or the country, I believe many Government party members will join me in opposing such a policy. Are they then considered the Opposition as well?

    The General Elections are long over. Seventy-five percent of the voting population voted for the governing party. The rest have rejected it and voted for the Opposition. Whatever the reasons, it is time for us to rise above party politics and work together for the common good. My alliance Chairman, Mr Chiam, had expressed that here is an important role for us to play as non-PAP MPs. Sir, I believe that role is to represent the sizeable minority of the population who have supported us. It is very important for the Government to respect their desires and work closely with us to close this political divide.

    Singapore is a very small and vulnerable country. It is very important for all of us to be objective, level-headed and not be adversarial for the sake of being adversarial.

    In summing up, Mr Speaker, Sir, being a non-Government party Member, and being the youngest in this House, I have spoken my mind without fear or favour. Now, I volunteer my services to the sub-committees in the remaking of Singapore and its economy. Will I be invited to participate? Or will we be excluded? I would like to look forward to a good working relationship with all Members to restructure and prosper Singapore in this uncertain world.

    Sir, with that, I support the motion to thank the President for his Speech.

    Mr Inderjit Singh (Ang Mo Kio): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the motion in the name of Mrs Lim Hwee Hua.

    Sir, the last five years have been very sobering years for the Government and the people of Singapore. While we saw about 30 years of almost uninterrupted

Column: 258

growth, except for a couple of short downturns, in the last five years, things have been very different. We have seen two successive recessions in a short span of five years, something that we never expected.

    With the awakening of the two sleeping giants in Asia, namely, China and India, the five tigers of the old industrial economy are facing tremendous threats. All these changes are going to redefine the rules of the game in the new economy. The five old tigers of Asia will have to search for new roles to play in this new economy while they struggle to redefine their models of economic development. Singapore is not alone in its quest to restructure its economy. All the five Asian tigers are very much at it and, so far, only South Korea seems to have had some success in restructuring, while Taiwan and Hong Kong are seeing a possible hollowing of their own domestic economies but are aggressively growing the external wing of their economy through China.

Remaking of Singapore Economy

    Sir, it is an opportune time for Singapore to be looking at how she can change herself. The industrialisation formula of the past, driven mainly by foreign direct investments, is in no way going to help us in the future. The future lies in an innovation-based economy, driven by entrepreneurs and private enterprise, participating in a global market where technologies and business models are constantly changing. We need bold new strategies to succeed.

    There are three fundamental points I would like to make on how we can find the right elements to successfully remake the Singapore economy. They are, firstly, changing the way we plan our economy; secondly, the economic colonisation model for Singapore; and finally, the role of Government in business, including GLCs.

    Sir, the remaking of the Singapore economy is everyone's business. The Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and everyone involved in the process

Column: 259

have invited every Singaporean to be involved and to come forward. So when Mr Steve Chia says that he hopes to be invited, I think he has already been invited. But he really needs to be a lot more proactive and take the initiative to do something about it to make proposals. I head the Indus entrepreneurs - and this is the chapter of entrepreneurs of Indian origin all around the world - and without the Government asking us, we have had about two months of activities in trying to come out with proposals in a few areas. In about two weeks' time, we will be ready to submit a report to the Government. So please do not sit and wait, do something about it.

Changing the way we plan our economy

    Sir, the first point I want to make is about changing the way we plan our economy from central planning to distributed planning and from a straight line planning to fuzzy planning process. Looking back, while being an impressive development, our first 30 years of economic development have really been driven by a fixed model of growth, planned centrally where straight line planning was workable because of the type of economy we were growing.

    In a straight line planning model, once we decided on the formula for growth, the rest was left to the administrators to plan and all they needed to do was to make straight line projections like the amount of foreign direct investments to bring in, number of jobs to create, number of training places to establish and other similar measures. The straight line planning model, driven by a strong central authority, managed by a few good men, worked because all we needed to do was to do more of the same and to do it better than our Asian neighbours.

    In the last five years, we have entered into the era of the new economy and we have quickly realised that our planning models and theories do not work well as evidenced by our inability to forecast the economy well. We have not only seen near misses, in fact we have seen huge

Column: 260

fluctuations and variations of what turned out to be the reality versus our expectations. The Government agencies have not been able to grasp the elements of the new economy because we cannot be planning an economy thinking narrowly within our own borders.

    In a globalised world, we have to think of the whole world as our market and when we do this, we will have to think of new models simply because the Government cannot possibly have influence outside our borders. The sure thing is that the Government alone can no longer monopolise and drive economic planning and development in the future. Economic colonisation

    My second point is one of economic colonisation - setting up of a true external wing. Singapore should aggressively embark on a colonisation programme. We have so far successfully developed the external wing of our economy and I feel the way forward is through this colonisation programme, which will accelerate the growth of our external economy. We have to start building Singapore all around the world. And I would like to suggest three ways that we can achieve this accelerated growth.

New model of globalisation

    Firstly, a new model of globalisation. Recently, there has been a lot of debate on how we can create local multinational companies. I feel that our failure in developing world-class companies may have been in the approach we are taking and Professor Peter Williamson of Insead University, who advises us on some of these things, very well summaries it, and I quote him:

    "A lot of Singaporean companies want to become multinational.     Professor Williamson rightly points out that if we try to copy the models of the big developed economies of the US, Europe and Japan, we will not succeed and, for Singapore with a small domestic economy, we will never be able to learn the true needs of the world market if we do not quickly go out of Singapore to do our businesses. What this means is that we do not necessarily have to take the traditional route of growing global businesses by first growing a successful domestic market before we embark on internationalisation. Many of our companies, especially the Government-linked companies, are still thinking of the old model, and I feel that they must start thinking differently by sometimes doing more globally than locally. The Israelis are the best examples of how local companies went straight into international markets like the US and Europe to become the world's best companies in a number of areas.     Sir, the third route to economic colonisation is by acquisition of businesses as an alternative to starting companies. Our entrepreneurs and enterprises should start thinking of alternative formulae of starting companies. The way forward may not necessarily be through brand-new start-ups but through acquisition of businesses and companies already successful in foreign countries. With our ability to raise funds and to tap funds and good management skills, we have the opportunity to take over businesses which have proven track records, and in areas where it may take too long for us to build up competencies if we start from scratch. Wessex specialises in supplying water and water-related activities to 1.2 million residents in the UK. Theirs is an example

Column: 265

of jump-starting a business, which may have taken too long to build up had they done it in a Greenfield manner. Importantly, they are diversifying away from a slumping domestic construction industry to new areas of competencies. We must learn from YTL of Malaysia.

    We have to go on the path of economic colonisation by developing our strengths, including all resources to be set up all over the world. We should be thinking of cultivating and harvesting competencies and capabilities from around the world as part of our formula of growing our economy. We have the means, the timing is right and opportunities all around the world are in abundance.

Role of Government in business

    Sir, the final point I would like to make today is the role of Government in business. Whether we like it or not, whether we want to admit it or not, the Government and Government-linked companies do have a significant impact on the Singapore economy, whether directly as business units or indirectly by crowding out private enterprise and the private sector, or through incentive and disincentive schemes operated by Government agencies.

    I feel that many of our GLCs have been operating too much in their comfort zones, being given too many privileges in the domestic economy and, therefore, unfairly beating private companies in competition with them in the local market. However, in the long term, success in the domestic economy alone is not sufficient as the whole world globalises. I personally feel that many of our GLCs will fail when they globalise and face global competition, where true market forces rule. We, therefore, need the Government and the Government-linked companies to find new roles and find a new strategic position for themselves in this global economy.

    Some of the elements, which could constitute a good strategic position for them in the future, are:

    Firstly, being globally-focused instead of locally-focused, and a spirit of partnership with other companies. With the increasing activity in global Free Trade Agreements, countries and companies will have to compete on a level playing field. While this will be a threat in the domestic market, it is also an opportunity which we should be ready to cultivate when the time comes. Our GLCs should, therefore, use their strengths to quickly go out and lead the way of economic colonisation and find success in globalisation, instead of working in their comfort zones at home. To do so, GLCs should also think about partnership with other local private companies or, for that matter, with other GLCs. The problem is that both GLCs and the private local companies have developed a culture of suspicion and distrust such that they seldom ventured into a collaboration approach by combining their core competencies to create a cluster of core competencies and then using this new combined strength to compete with large foreign companies, either locally or globally. I feel we can best globalise if we work on pooling our competencies together and with a spirit of partnership where each company, whether big or small, contributes in creating very strong clusters capable of competing with the best companies from around the world.

While we can accept that GLCs had a role to play in our economic development and still have a role to play in the future, it is not quite right for statutory boards to get involved in businesses. Over the years, we have seen many instances of statutory boards getting into businesses, which compete head-on with the private sector, and this definitely leads to unfair competition because of the strong backing of the Government agencies they are in. The Government needs to have more trust in the private sector and develop a culture of outsourcing as many activities as possible, especially to the private sector, and not only to the GLCs. Similarly, Temasek and other Government agencies should actively look out for opportunities to proactively divest companies which

For example, it makes no sense to ask that the Government divests SIA or PSA, because these are areas we obviously have world-class competencies and the current structures will work well in the future. The king replied, "Of course, not, it is ridiculous. This is Wei state. We are a peaceful country."
